data.text: Any of various nocturnal flying mammals of the order Chiroptera, having membranous wings that extend from the forelimbs to the hind limbs or tail and anatomical adaptations for echolocation, by which they navigate and hunt prey.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: (have bats in (one's) belfry) To behave in an eccentric, bizarre manner.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A stout wooden stick; a cudgel.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A blow, such as one delivered with a stick.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A rounded, often wooden club, wider and heavier at the hitting end and tapering at the handle, used to strike the ball.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A club used in cricket, having a broad, flat-surfaced hitting end and a distinct, narrow handle.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The racket used in various games, such as table tennis or racquets.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To hit with or as if with a bat.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
